api:field.name: abstract
api:field.api:text: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p> <jats:bold> <jats:italic>Introduction</jats:italic> </jats:bold>: We previously demonstrated that 60% ethanol increased macromolecular leakage and induced lesion formation in areas of permanent flow stasis within gastric mucosal vessels. Mast cells and their mediators have been implicated in acute mucosal injury. Fluorescent <jats:italic>in vivo</jats:italic> microscopy was used to assess the effects of ketotifen, a mast cell stabilizer, and pyrilamine, a histamine (H<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>)‐receptor antagonist, on ethanol‐induced rat gastric mucosal injury.</jats:p><jats:p> <jats:bold> <jats:italic>Methods</jats:italic> </jats:bold>: Experiments were carried out on anaesthetized rats pretreated orally with ketotifen (1 mg/kg) or pyrilamine (30 mg/kg). Fluorescein isothiocyanate–bovine serum albumin (FITC‐BSA; 0.2 mL/100 g), a marker for quantitating macromolecular leakage was administered intra‐arterially. Ethanol (60%) or distilled water was applied topically to the gastric mucosa. Macromolecular leakage of FITC‐BSA, vessel diameters and leucocyte activity were quantified using image analysis.</jats:p><jats:p> <jats:bold> <jats:italic>Results</jats:italic> </jats:bold>: Pretreatment with ketotifen or pyrilamine, followed by ethanol, caused no change in macromolecular leakage compared with controls. Both compounds prevented blood flow stasis in all areas and no lesion formation was observed. However, increased leucocyte activity and increases in vessel diameter were observed following pretreatment with ketotifen and pyrilamine, respectively.</jats:p><jats:p> <jats:bold> <jats:italic>Conclusions</jats:italic> </jats:bold>: The data suggest that vasoactive substances released from mast cells may be involved in the aetiology of ethanol‐induced gastric mucosal damage. The prevention of these normal physiological responses to injury may lead to the employment of other microcirculatory mechanisms of defence.</jats:p>

api:field.name: title
api:field.api:text: Mast cell stabilization prevents ethanol‐induced rat gastric mucosal injury: Mechanisms of protection

api:field.name: abstract
api:field.api:text: Introduction: We previously demonstrated that 60% ethanol increased macromolecular leakage and induced lesion formation in areas of permanent flow stasis within gastric mucosal vessels. Mast cells and their mediators have been implicated in acute mucosal injury. Fluorescent in vivo microscopy was used to assess the effects of ketotifen, a mast cell stabilizer, and pyrilamine, a histamine (H1)-receptor antagonist, on ethanol-induced rat gastric mucosal injury. Methods: Experiments were carried out on anaesthetized rats pretreated orally with ketotifen (1 mg/kg) or pyrilamine (30 mg/kg). Fluorescein isothiocyanate-bovine serum albumin (FITC-BSA; 0.2 mL/100 g), a marker for quantitating macromolecular leakage was administered intra-arterially. Ethanol (60%) or distilled water was applied topically to the gastric mucosa. Macromolecular leakage of FITC-BSA, vessel diameters and leucocyte activity were quantified using image analysis. Results: Pretreatment with ketotifen or pyrilamine, followed by ethanol, caused no change in macromolecular leakage compared with controls. Both compounds prevented blood flow stasis in all areas and no lesion formation was observed. However, increased leucocyte activity and increases in vessel diameter were observed following pretreatment with ketotifen and pyrilamine, respectively. Conclusions: The data suggest that vasoactive substances released from mast cells may be involved in the aetiology of ethanol-induced gastric mucosal damage. The prevention of these normal physiological responses to injury may lead to the employment of other microcirculatory mechanisms of defence. (C) 2000 Blackwell Science Asia Pty Ltd.

api:field.name: title
api:field.api:text: Mast cell stabilization prevents ethanol-induced rat gastric mucosal injury: Mechanisms of protection

api:field.name: abstract
api:field.api:text: INTRODUCTION: We previously demonstrated that 60% ethanol increased macromolecular leakage and induced lesion formation in areas of permanent flow stasis within gastric mucosal vessels. Mast cells and their mediators have been implicated in acute mucosal injury. Fluorescent in vivo microscopy was used to assess the effects of ketotifen, a mast cell stabilizer, and pyrilamine, a histamine (H1)-receptor antagonist, on ethanol-induced rat gastric mucosal injury. METHODS: Experiments were carried out on anaesthetized rats pretreated orally with ketotifen (1 mg/kg) or pyrilamine (30 mg/kg). Fluorescein isothiocyanate-bovine serum albumin (FITC-BSA; 0.2 mL/100 g), a marker for quantitating macromolecular leakage was administered intra-arterially. Ethanol (60%) or distilled water was applied topically to the gastric mucosa. Macromolecular leakage of FITC-BSA, vessel diameters and leucocyte activity were quantified using image analysis. RESULTS: Pretreatment with ketotifen or pyrilamine, followed by ethanol, caused no change in macromolecular leakage compared with controls. Both compounds prevented blood flow stasis in all areas and no lesion formation was observed. However, increased leucocyte activity and increases in vessel diameter were observed following pretreatment with ketotifen and pyrilamine, respectively. CONCLUSIONS: The data suggest that vasoactive substances released from mast cells may be involved in the aetiology of ethanol-induced gastric mucosal damage. The prevention of these normal physiological responses to injury may lead to the employment of other microcirculatory mechanisms of defence.

api:address.api:line: Department of Surgical and Anaesthetic Sciences, Royal Hallamshire Hospital, Sheffield, United Kingdom. N.Kalia@sheffield.ac.uk

api:field.name: title
api:field.api:text: Mast cell stabilization prevents ethanol-induced rat gastric mucosal injury: mechanisms of protection.

api:field.name: abstract
api:field.api:text:
Introduction

We previously demonstrated that 60% ethanol increased macromolecular leakage and induced lesion formation in areas of permanent flow stasis within gastric mucosal vessels. Mast cells and their mediators have been implicated in acute mucosal injury. Fluorescent in vivo microscopy was used to assess the effects of ketotifen, a mast cell stabilizer, and pyrilamine, a histamine (H1)-receptor antagonist, on ethanol-induced rat gastric mucosal injury.

Methods

Experiments were carried out on anaesthetized rats pretreated orally with ketotifen (1 mg/kg) or pyrilamine (30 mg/kg). Fluorescein isothiocyanate-bovine serum albumin (FITC-BSA; 0.2 mL/100 g), a marker for quantitating macromolecular leakage was administered intra-arterially. Ethanol (60%) or distilled water was applied topically to the gastric mucosa. Macromolecular leakage of FITC-BSA, vessel diameters and leucocyte activity were quantified using image analysis.

Results

Pretreatment with ketotifen or pyrilamine, followed by ethanol, caused no change in macromolecular leakage compared with controls. Both compounds prevented blood flow stasis in all areas and no lesion formation was observed. However, increased leucocyte activity and increases in vessel diameter were observed following pretreatment with ketotifen and pyrilamine, respectively.

Conclusions

The data suggest that vasoactive substances released from mast cells may be involved in the aetiology of ethanol-induced gastric mucosal damage. The prevention of these normal physiological responses to injury may lead to the employment of other microcirculatory mechanisms of defence.

api:address.api:line: Department of Surgical and Anaesthetic Sciences, Royal Hallamshire Hospital, Sheffield, United Kingdom. N.Kalia@sheffield.ac.uk
